answers.answer: Sorry to hear about the run around. I've been dealing with a lot running around myself. I ended up going to a new endocrinologist. I can have sympathy for you as far as trying to get past the "girls" at the reception desk. It's nearly impossible these days to directly speak to your doctor without an appointment. Try being firm and persistant with them and if it doesn't work maybe it's time to change to a more caring doctor's office.

Thanks for your post.  Actually, a friend of mine went ballistic when I told her about my primary care doctor's 'psychiatrist' comment.  She made the same suggestion as you did - look for another doctor.  Guess it's time for me to take that advice.  I just hope I'm more successful with this going forward.

Sounds like symptoms of hypothyroidism.  Once you are at the right levels for YOU, symptoms should subside, however, it takes time heal thereafter.   Two months is not long enough for the body to heal.  After that, if you are not satisfied with doctors, can you fire them? and find one who IS willing to work with you?"psychiatrist" how insulting! Fire him!Keep in mind that fiber diet can interfere with thyroid med. absorption and influence levels. If you are going to be on that type of diet, be consistent.Sharp stomach pain and diarrhea I have no clue, but, and including the high BP, could be stress from all the doctors. Fire them! ;)  I feel for ya!Good Luck!

I got the "psychiatrist" referral after giving birth with a now defunct HMO.  The delivery was horrible and my colon ended up being perforated.  When the doctor suggested a psychiatrist I informed him that psychiatrists deal with the wrong end and let him know what I thought of his credentials and his HMO.I've fired a few doctors and it sounds like you have two you need to fire.  Please get a referral to another endocrinologist.  Do you have any friends who are seeing one or is there a support group you could ask?  Patients are great judges of doctors.I'm wondering if your stomach/intestinal problems could be IBS.  Stress and hormonal imbalances (um . . . like having your thyroid removed) can really set IBS off.GravesLady hit it right on the head - thyroid levels need to be correct for YOU, not just to please some lab.  You sound hypo.  Are you also cold and tired all the time?Another thing that can block thyroid medication absorbtion is calcium.  Make sure you don't have ANY calcium for a couple of hours before or after your thyroid medication.  Are you *ON* any thyroid medication?  If not, you probably should be.It can take the body months to level out after thyroid surgery and since yours was only over two months ago you probably haven't stabalized.  Even if your labs are "normal" now they might NOT be soon.Do some doctor shopping and quickly!!!

Thanks for your post.  You made me smile! : )  One of the mistakes I make here, and maybe others here will agree), is that I read the posts where someone will have had the same surgery, just breezed along without any symptoms and was back to work in a week - so I think "...well, I should be doing that too!"  Thanks for the reminder that we're all different.I was warned that finding the right meds levels for me might be tricky - I just didn't know HOW tricky it might be.  Regardless, just when I thought I'd heard it all from doctor's, one of them blows me away again.  Funny - years ago, I thought doctors were GODS!  How nice to realize that they are just mere mortals with inflated egos.  LOL!Thanks for the tip about the fiber!  (See - my doctors never mentioned that!)  I think I'll just stick to the fiber I'm getting in my regular food intake, so as to not interfere with my meds, especially since I'm going back on Weight Watchers to lose the 20 lbs I've gained.Thanks, Graveslady!  I love this site - everyone is so helpful and supportive here!

One thing I forgot to mention.  Following TT two sisters and I developed diabetes.  Have you had your blood sugar levels checked?Diabetes *could* be tied to your weight gain, blood pressure problems, and your flu-like symptoms.  If you don't have a glucose monitor, see if you can borrow one (change the needle though!), or buy one.If you are having blood sugar issues you'll need to control your carbohydrate intake.  The best diet for that is the one from the American Diabetes Association but Atkins or South Beach are pretty close (South Beach seems to be healthier, especially if you are having blood pressure problems).Hang in there and find a good endo - endos handle blood sugars as well as thyroid problems so mention the weight gain, blood pressure, and flu-like symptoms.

I wanted to tell you that you aren't alone.  I had a tt in April of '06.  I then underwent RAI treatment for cancer.  The very day I had my RAI treatment I started with the diahrea and vomitting.  I thought it was nerves so didn't really worry about it.  It is now nearly 6 months later and on an average of 5 times a week I have diahrea.  It doesn't matter what I eat, if it is going to happen it will happen.  I asked the doctors about it because I am linking it to the RAI and they just said no one has ever had that side effect before and ignore it.  I really like my doctor so I haven't pushed the issue too much I just always make sure I have imodium ad with me at all times.  Let me know if you find some answers.

question: I underwent a total thyroidectomy on 8-21-06.  (I had severe hyperthyroidism before the surgery).  The surgery went fine, but I started having flu-like symptoms one week after the surgery that have not subsided.  The skin on my face and neck is also now very dry and itchy, as well as on my entire upper body.  I'm also experiencing sharp stomach pains and diarrhea about 4 days a week, have gained 20 lbs in the two months since the surgery and my blood pressure is now pretty high, 153/96.I had an appointment with my primary care for these symptoms two weeks ago, where he simply advised me to use moisturizer regularly and to eat more fiber in my diet, then see him back in two weeks.  He ended the appointment by telling me if I felt I could not return to work on Nov 1st, he would have to arrange for me to see a psychiatrist.  I was floored.  I'm not crazy, I'm just feeling like **** physically!!Today, I called the endocrinologist who treated me before the surgery to make an appt with him to discuss my symptoms.  His assistant just referred me back to my primary care, pending a call back from the endocrinologist, stating that since my current blood work shows my thyroid levels now in the normal range, (they are, but just barely), I have to go through my primary care doctor for treatment of my current symptoms.I'm starting to feel like I'm about to fall through the cracks here.  I'm not crazy, I just need these issues treated, but my Endo is pushing me back to my primary care, who just infers that I'm crazy.  Any suggestions will be MUCH appreciated.
title: Receiving run-around by doctor's after total thyroidectomy
